author: lightclient
content: Unfortunately the fact is that a large number projects within the ecosystem (including the eth2 launch pad!) rely on Infura. For that reason, I think they should be in the equation when determining the health of the Ethereum network.

author: sky.cactus
content: I would *like* it if we developed strategies that worked when things aren't centralized, rather than developing strategies that only work when things are centralized.

author: sky.cactus
content: In this case, we should have a system in place for responsible disclosure in a timely fashion of concensus bugs that any participant in the system can receive, not only "big participants".

author: lightclient
content: The problem is that if "big participants" find out at the same time as everyone, they will be susceptible to being exploited by the vulnerability while they attempt to patch

author: sky.cactus
content: So will small participants.

author: sky.cactus
content: Also, this is why I proposed https://discordapp.com/channels/595666850260713488/745077610685661265/776055184857235486, it both provides a responsible disclosure timeline to *all* participants without favoring anyone in particular, while at the same time hopefully buying time for people to upgrade in different tiers of responsiveness.

author: sky.cactus
content: It feels a bit against the ethos of Ethereum to give preferential treatment to large ecosystem participants (such as secret early access to bug reports) while small ecosystem participants don't have a mechanism for receiving similar advanced notice.
